title: Several arrests are made in murder investigation of American prosecutor shot dead in Yap
text:
Police have made several arrests in the investigation into the murder of the American prosecutor who was murdered outside her home on the island of Yap, it was confirmed Monday.

Rachelle Bergeron, 33, who was originally from Wisconsin, was shot three times on October 14 on the tiny Pacific island of Yap after coming back from a run.

She is said to have told her husband, Simon Hammerling, she feared for her life due to the dangerous nature of her job working on child trafficking cases.

Governor Henry S. Falan confirmed the arrests in a statement Monday, saying 'next stage in the investigation will be the court proceedings as the State moves toward the final stage of conviction'.

He added: 'No names will be issued by the authorities at this time. We will keep the public informed at the appropriate time as the court case moves ahead.'

Her husband Simon said he found her body outside of their home, along with one of their dogs, who may have been trying to protect her.

Authorities in Micronesia said Monday they arrested suspects in the slaying of an American prosecutor Rachelle Bergeron who was working as acting attorney general of the state of Yap

Yap Gov. Henry S. Falan announced the arrests on the state's website. No names were released. Rachelle Bergeron was fatally shot October 14 after returning home from a run. Her friends believe her killing was tied to her work, which including being part of a human-trafficking task force. Rachelle is pictured on her wedding day to husband Simon Hammerling

The killing has shocked the tiny island of Yap, home to 11,000 people

'She wanted justice and to help everybody,' Rachelle’s mother, Tammy Bergeron said to Inside Edition. 'She had this beautiful balance between justice and doing right, but also compassion and love for other people.'

Rachelle's husband Simon said: 'When this whole thing went down, I was screaming and I think everyone on the island could hear me cry.'

Rachelle spent her life battling sex traffickers in the US and worked as a New York human rights lawyer before she moved to the tiny Micronesian island to continue her work there.

In 2014 she helped produce the PSA 'Not So Super' that raised awareness about sex trafficking at the 2014 Super Bowl in New Jersey.

'From [a] young [age], she always had this idea she wanted to be in the F.B.I.,' her father Tom Bergeron said.

Her sister Emily and brothers Nick and Ryan were seen carrying an empty casket at the service, as her real body was transported to Dover, Delaware in the U.S. for an autopsy

Yap has a reported problem with the sex trafficking of underage girls to merchant marine crews that anchor in its harbors.

She and her husband were planning to adopt a 12-year-old girl named Deesha who they found sleeping on their front porch one morning. They wanted to bring her back to the U.S. with them.

'She was like a mother to me,' Deesha said. 'Really so much more.'

An emotional memorial service took place on Yap earlier this month where hundreds gathered to pay their respects.

Her sister Emily and brothers Nick and Ryan were seen carrying an empty casket at the service, as her real body was transported to Dover, Delaware in the U.S. for an autopsy.

Friends believe her death was related to her work as acting attorney general of Yap State. Her duties included being part of a human-trafficking task force, and friends say some criminals may have held a grudge against her.

'She had this beautiful balance between justice and doing right, but also compassion and love for other people,' Rachelle’s mother, Tammy Bergeron, said. Pictured above with Rachelle's father Tom Bergeron and the 12-year-old girl Deesha she wanted to adopt

Rachelle Bergeron was killed last week in the Pacific nation of Micronesia after returning home from a run with her dog. Police have identified 'several' persons of interest in her murder

Bergeron had 'the most dangerous job in Yap' fighting sex traffickers and domestic abusers,' Amos Collins, a family friend, in an interview with ABC.

Friends said she had received so many threats in her job and she was looking forward to returning to the US.

In an interview with Good Morning America, Hammerling choked back tears as he described the 'impact' she had on the community.

'I heard gunshots, three shots, really loud. I didn't see any of the shooter and stuff. I saw Rachelle and our dog dead... I just kind of fell by her, not really thinking anything else,' he said.

The pair were about to celebrate their first wedding anniversary.
description: Rachelle Bergeron, pictured left and on her wedding day right, from Wisconsin, was shot three times on October 14 in Yap. Gov Henry S. Falan announced the arrests. No names were released.
